comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: Faggot cutter – one who clears brush (?) – or maybe one who gathers sticks/firewood (?) faggot (1) (Dictionary com) 1279, "bundle of twigs bound up," from O.Fr. fagot "bundle of sticks," from It. faggotto, dim. of V.L. *facus, from L. fascis "bundle of wood" (see fasces).

comment.author: 24506419@N08
comment._content:
I heard the term "Flaming Faggot" , came from these days when they would burn "gay" people
in these twigs (faggots) and burn witches on a stake? I have no idea if this is true, but it's good to see we have come so far since then......

comment.author: 30817808@N00
comment._content: In Ireland they also had 'peat cutters' for fuel from dried from the bogs.

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/celtico] 

And remember, after a while, the peat cutters began unearthing preserved ("tanned") remains, which at first they thought were recent murder victims!

Upon extensive investigation, it was found that the so-called "Bog People" (LOVE that name and title of the first book I know about them) involved neolithic burials, probably sacrifices to gods and goddesses, or possibly execution of criminals!

After the first few, they began to be found all over northern Europe.

comment.author: 30817808@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/64838194@N02] 
Yes the neolithic culture via myth and legend imprinted longer on the later arrivals of Celts or other Iron Age farmers .

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/celtico] Good point, Mike (long time no hear!). No wonder so many of their myths (like Beowulf have such gruesome undertones, or even themes. Neolithic culture in that area tended toward what we see as bizarre or gruesome. I wonder how they saw it....?

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31580040@N04]  Perhaps I wasn't clear; I meant that the early Neolithic stories were handed down to the Celts and others, just as Sumerian and other flood myths (etc.) were incorporated into the Hebrew bible.
